conclusion: Block C starts with an initial velocity v_0 and moves a distance s_0 before colliding with block B.
The frictional force acts on block C over the distance s_0, doing work and changing its kinetic energy.

premise: The work done by friction on block C is W = -μmg s_0.
conclusion: Apply the work-energy principle: 1/2 m v_0^2 + W = 1/2 m v_1^2 where v_1 is the velocity of block C just before the collision.
The collision is perfectly inelastic, meaning C and B stick together.

premise: Initial momentum: m v_1, Final momentum: (m + m) v_2 = 2m v_2
conclusion: Apply conservation of momentum: m v_1 = 2m v_2

premise: Initial kinetic energy of C before collision: 1/2 m v_1^2, Final kinetic energy of C and B after collision: 1/2 (2m) v_2^2
conclusion: Energy loss ΔE: ΔE = 1/2 m v_1^2 - 1/2 (2m) v_2^2
